mathslib package¶

Submodules¶

mathslib.numtheory module¶

Various Number Theory functions

Author: Igor van Loo

mathslib.numtheory.ChineseRemainderTheorem(a1, a2, n1, n2)[source]¶

Simple Chinese Remiander Theorem to solve x = a1 mod n1, x = a2 mod n2

a1 : An integer a2 : An integer n1 : An integer n2 : An integer

Unique solution x = a1 mod n1, x = a2 mod n2

mathslib.numtheory.Mobius(n)[source]¶

Finds the mobius function of n See here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/M%C3%B6bius_function

n : An integer

returns 0 if n is divisible by p^2 otherwise returns (-1)^k, where k is number of distinct prime factors

mathslib.numtheory.continued_fraction(x)[source]¶

Finds the continued Fraction of the sqrt(x) See here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continued_fraction

x : An integer

temp_listA list

Contains the continued fraction of n

mathslib.numtheory.divisor(x, n)[source]¶

Implementation of Divisor function σ_x(n) (See here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Divisor_function#Definition)

xAn integer,

x = 0 - Gives you number of divisors x = 1 - Gives you sum of divisors x = 2 - Gives you sum of divisors squared

n : An integer, number to function σ_x of

total : Returns σ_x(n)

mathslib.numtheory.divisors_of(x, include_x=True)[source]¶

Finds all the divisors of x

x : An integer

divisors : a list containing all the divisors of x

mathslib.numtheory.k_smooth_numbers(max_prime, limit)[source]¶

Find all k ≤ max_prime smooth numbers up till a limit See here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smooth_number

max_prime : A prime limit : An integer

A list containing all k ≤ max_prime smooth numbers less that limit

mathslib.numtheory.legendre_factorial(x)[source]¶

Implementation of Legendres’ Formula See here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Legendre%27s_formula

x : An integer

Returns a list containing the prime factorisation of x!

mathslib.numtheory.legendre_symbol(a, p)[source]¶

Finds the legendre symbol of a/p See here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Legendre_symbol

a : An integer p : An odd prime

Returns the legendre symbol of a/p: 1 if a is a quadratic residue modulo p and p does not divide a -1 if a is a non-quadratic residue modulo p 0 if p divides a

mathslib.numtheory.overall_fraction(cf)[source]¶
cflist

Takes a list containing the continued fraction of a number, returns the fraction

denominatorTYPE

DESCRIPTION.

numeratorTYPE

DESCRIPTION.

mathslib.numtheory.phi(n)[source]¶

Eulers Totient Function counts the positive integers up to a given integer n that are relatively prime to n See here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Euler%27s_totient_function

n : An integer

The number of integers, a, less than n, such that gcd(a, n) = 1

mathslib.numtheory.ppt(limit, non_primitive=True)[source]¶

Generates all Pythagorean Triplets up till the limit See here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pythagorean_triple

limitTYPE

DESCRIPTION.

non_primitiveOptional

If you want only primitive pythagorean Triplets set this to False

triples : A list containing all your desired type of triplets (Based on non_primitive)

mathslib.numtheory.tonelli_shanks(a, p)[source]¶

Credit to: https://eli.thegreenplace.net/2009/03/07/computing-modular-square-roots-in-python/ Implementation of Tonelli Shanks algorithm See here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tonelli%E2%80%93Shanks_algorithm

a : An integer p : An integer

Solve the congruence of the form:

x^2 = a (mod p)

And returns x. Note that p - x is also a root.

0 is returned is no square root exists for these a and p.

mathslib.primes module¶

Prime related functions

Author: Igor van Loo

mathslib.primes.Prime_Sieve(limit, block_size=0, segment=False, values=True)[source]¶

A prime sieve I made with a few different options

limit : The limit up till which the function will generate primes block_size : Decide which length of blocks you would like to cut the sieve into, automatically it is set to sqrt(limit) segment : Decide whether you would like to use a segmented sieve or a regular sieve, it is normally set it False values : If segment == False, if you would like an actual list of prime then values is true, if you would

like an array such that array[x] = True if x is prime, then set values = False

Based on above, all primes less than limit or an array such that array[x] = True if x is prime

mathslib.primes.is_prime(x)[source]¶

A simple is prime function, checks if a number is prime

x : The number to be checked

True if x is prime False if x is not prime

mathslib.primes.prime_factors(n)[source]¶

Finds all the prime factors of n

n : Finds the prime factors of n

A dictionary containing the prime divisors as keys and value as the corresponding exponent of the prime

mathslib.primes.primepi(limit)[source]¶

Primepi function is commonly known as Prime Counting Function (see here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime-counting_function)

This function generates an array such that array[x] = primepi(x)

limit : An integer, it will generate an array of length limit

array : array[x] = primepi(x)

mathslib.primes.sum_of_primes(n)[source]¶

Ultra fast sum of Primes made by Lucy The HedgeHog on Project Euler

n : An integer, will sum primes up till n

The sum of all primes up till n

mathslib.fib module¶

Fibonacci related functions

Author: Igor van Loo

mathslib.fib.ZeckendorfRepresentation(x)[source]¶

Finds the Zeckendorf Representation of x See here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zeckendorf%27s_theorem

x : An integer x

zeckrep : A list containing the zeckendorf representation of x

mathslib.fib.fib_till(limit)[source]¶

Finds all fibonnaci number up till a limit

limitTYPE

DESCRIPTION.

fibnumbers : A list containing all the fibonacci numbers < x

mathslib.fib.fibonacci(n)[source]¶

Finds the n-th fibonnaci using matrix exponentiation Credit: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/18172257/efficient-calculation-of-fibonacci-series/23462371#23462371

n : An integer

The n-th fibonnaci number

mathslib.algorithms module¶

Various known algorithms, graph theory and optimization related

Author: Igor van Loo

mathslib.algorithms.DijkstrasAlgorithm(matrix, start_node=(0, 0), end_node=(- 1, - 1))[source]¶

Dijkstra’s algorithm is an algorithm for finding the shortest paths between nodes in a graph See here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dijkstra%27s_algorithm Implementation is based of Wikipedia

matrix : Takes a matrix input, representing the graph, assumes all nodes are connected

Shortest path between desired starting and ending node

mathslib.algorithms.KnapSack(values, weights, n, W, no_values=True)[source]¶

Given a set of items, each with a weight and a value, determine the number of each item to include in a collection so that the total weight is less than or equal to a given limit and the total value is as large as possible See here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knapsack_problem

values : A list of values weights : A list with weight of corresponding values n : Number of items (len(values)) W : Desired weight no_values : TYPE, optional

Default is True

If no_values == True - It returns the optimal sum of weights If no_values == False - it returns the entire array, which is used in KnapSackValues to find which values were actually used in the optimal sum

mathslib.algorithms.KnapSackValues(values, weights, n, W)[source]¶

Extension to KnapSack function It finds the actual values used to obtain the optimal sum

values : A list of values weights : A list with weight of corresponding values n : Number of items (len(values)) W : Desired weight

A set with the optimal values

mathslib.algorithms.PrimsAlgorithm(matrix)[source]¶

Prim’s algorithm is a greedy algorithm that finds a minimum spanning tree for a weighted undirected graph. See here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prim%27s_algorithm Implementation is based of Wikipedia

graph : Takes a matrix input

The minimum spanning tree for the weighted undirected Graph

mathslib.simple module¶

Various simple functions

Author: Igor van Loo

mathslib.simple.ModDivision(a, b, m)[source]¶

Finds a/b mod m

a : An integer, the numerator b : An integer, the denominator m : An integer, the modulus

answer : a/b mod m

mathslib.simple.lcm(a_list)[source]¶

Finds the lcm of a list of numbers

a_list : A list of numbers

curr : The lcm of all numbers in the list

mathslib.simple.n_choose_r(n, r)[source]¶

n choose r function

nTYPE

DESCRIPTION.

rTYPE

DESCRIPTION.

TYPE

DESCRIPTION.

mathslib.simple.numberToBase(n, b)[source]¶

Changes n from base 10 to base b

n : An integer, number to be changed b : An integer, base in question

n in base b
